tabs.label: President
tabs.title: President of India (Art 52-62)

sections.heading: Constitutional Provision
points: **Art 52**: There shall be a President of India
**Art 53**: Executive power of Union vested in President; Exercised directly or through officers subordinate to him
**Art 58**: Qualifications - Indian citizen, 35+ years, qualified to be LS member, not holding office of profit
**Nominal Head**: In Parliamentary system, President is nominal/ceremonial head; PM is real executive
**Part of Parliament**: Art 79 - Parliament = President + Lok Sabha + Rajya Sabha

sections.heading: Election & Oath
points: **Art 54**: Elected by Electoral College (MPs + MLAs of all States + Delhi, Puducherry, J&K)
**Art 55**: System of Proportional Representation by Single Transferable Vote (STV); Secret ballot
**Uniform scale**: Value of vote calculated to maintain uniformity between States and between States & Union
**Formula**: MLA vote value = (State Population / Total MLAs) Ã· 1000; MP vote value = Total MLAs vote value / Total MPs
**Term**: 5 years from date of entering office (Art 56); Can resign anytime (to VP); Removable by impeachment
**Re-election**: Can be re-elected any number of times (no term limit like USA)
**Oath**: Art 60 - Oath to preserve, protect, defend Constitution and law; Administered by CJI or senior-most SC judge
**Salary**: â‚¹5 lakh/month (earlier â‚¹1.5 lakh; increased 2018); Charged on Consolidated Fund of India

sections.heading: Impeachment
points: **Art 61**: Removal by impeachment for 'violation of Constitution'
**Procedure**:
â€¢ Charge framed by either House of Parliament
â€¢ Notice signed by 1/4th members of House; 14 days' notice
â€¢ Resolution passed by 2/3rd majority of total membership of that House
â€¢ Other House investigates charges (acts as court)
â€¢ President has right to appear and be represented
â€¢ If charges proved by 2/3rd of total membership of investigating House â†’ President removed
**Grounds**: 'Violation of Constitution' (not defined; Wide scope)
**Never used**: No President impeached so far; Only once initiated (against President K.R. Narayanan - withdrawn)

sections.heading: Executive Powers (Art 53, 73, 77)
points: **Appointments**: Appoints PM, Council of Ministers (Art 75), CJI & SC/HC judges (Art 124, 217), CAG (Art 148), Attorney General (Art 76), Election Commissioners (Art 324), Governors (Art 155), UPSC Chairman & members (Art 316)
**Administration**: All executive actions of Union taken in name of President (Art 77); But bound by Cabinet advice (Art 74)
**Foreign affairs**: Represents India internationally; Receives foreign dignitaries; Appoints ambassadors (Entry 10 Union List)
**Defence**: Supreme Commander of Armed Forces (Art 53); But cannot declare war (Cabinet decides)
**Emergency**: Proclaims National Emergency (Art 352), President's Rule (Art 356), Financial Emergency (Art 360) - On Cabinet advice

sections.heading: Legislative Powers
points: **Part of Parliament**: Bills become law only after President's assent (Art 111)
**Summon/Prorogue**: Can summon, prorogue Parliament; Dissolve Lok Sabha (Art 85) - On PM's advice
**Address Parliament**: Addresses first session after each General Election and first session of each year (Art 87)
**Messages**: Can send messages to either House on pending Bills (Art 86)
**Nominates members**: 12 to Rajya Sabha (Art 80(1)), 2 Anglo-Indians to Lok Sabha (abolished 104th Amendment 2019)
**Appoints**: Speaker/Deputy Speaker of LS (Art 93), Chairman's Panel in RS
**Lays reports**: Laid before Parliament - CAG, Finance Commission, UPSC, SC/ST Commission reports

sections.heading: Financial Powers
points: **Money Bills**: Can be introduced only with President's recommendation (Art 117)
**Budget**: Annual Financial Statement (Budget) laid before Parliament in President's name (Art 112)
**Consolidated Fund**: All revenues, loans, expenditures flow to/from Consolidated Fund of India (Art 266); Operated by President
**Contingency Fund**: Controls Contingency Fund of India (Art 267); Can make advances for unforeseen expenditure
**Finance Commission**: Constitutes Finance Commission every 5 years (Art 280)
**Grants**: Can make grants from Consolidated Fund for any public purpose (Art 282)

sections.heading: Judicial Powers
points: **Appoints judges**: CJI and SC judges (Art 124), HC CJs and judges (Art 217) - On advice of collegium
**Pardoning power (Art 72)**: Can grant pardons, reprieves, respites, remissions, suspend/remit/commute sentences
â€¢ **Scope**: In all cases (court-martial, Union law violations, death sentences)
â€¢ **Types**: Pardon (completely absolves), Commutation (reduce sentence), Remission (reduce period), Reprieve (temporary suspension), Respite (award lesser sentence)
â€¢ **Wider than Governor**: President can pardon death sentences; Governor cannot
â€¢ **Not a court**: President not bound by court's view; But usually acts on Cabinet/Home Ministry advice
**Seeks advice**: Can seek advisory opinion of SC on questions of law/fact (Art 143)

sections.heading: Veto Powers (Art 111)
points: **Absolute Veto**: Withhold assent to Bill (Bill dies); Used for Private Member Bills
**Suspensive Veto**: Return Bill (except Money Bill) to Parliament for reconsideration; If re-passed, President MUST give assent
**Pocket Veto**: Keep Bill pending indefinitely (neither assent nor return); Take no action - Bill hangs
**Constitutional amendments**: President MUST give assent (Art 368(2)); Cannot use veto (but can delay)

sections.heading: Ordinance Making Power (Art 123)
points: **When**: Parliament not in session, and President satisfied immediate action needed
**Same force as Act**: Ordinance has same force and effect as Act of Parliament
**Duration**: 6 weeks from Parliament reassembles; Must be approved by Parliament within 6 weeks, else lapses
**Can be withdrawn**: President can withdraw anytime
**Limitations**: Cannot amend Constitution; Cannot be issued if Bill pending in Parliament on same matter; Must be laid before Parliament
**42nd Amendment**: Extended power to promulgate Ordinances even when one House in session (if other House not in session)
**Misuse**: Often misused to bypass Parliament; D.C. Wadhwa case (1987) - SC criticized repeated re-promulgation

sections.heading: Discretionary Powers
points: **Art 74 (before 42nd Amendment)**: President could act in his discretion in some matters
**42nd Amendment 1976**: Made President bound by Cabinet advice in ALL matters (removed discretion)
**44th Amendment 1978**: President can ask Cabinet to reconsider advice ONCE; But bound by reconsidered advice
**Current position**: President acts on Cabinet advice in all matters; Very limited/no discretion
**Situations where President may exercise judgment** (debated):
â€¢ Appointing PM (if no clear majority - Art 75)
â€¢ Dissolving LS (if PM loses majority but doesn't resign)
â€¢ Returning Bill for reconsideration (Art 111)
â€¢ Seeking clarification from Cabinet on advice

tabs.summary: **President**: Nominal head; Elected by Electoral College (MPs + MLAs) via STV; 5-year term; Removable by impeachment (Art 61 - violation of Constitution); Acts on Cabinet advice (Art 74 - 44th Amendment). **Powers**: Appoints PM, CMs (Governors), CJI, CAG, EC, AG; Part of Parliament; Money Bills need recommendation; Pardoning power (Art 72); Ordinance (Art 123 - 6 weeks). **Veto**: Absolute, Suspensive, Pocket. **Discretion**: Very limited after 44th Amendment.

tabs.label: Vice President
tabs.title: Vice President of India (Art 63-71)

sections.heading: Constitutional Provision
points: **Art 63**: There shall be a Vice President of India
**Art 64**: VP is **ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha** (does not preside over Lok Sabha)
**Art 65**: VP acts as President when President unable to discharge functions (death, resignation, removal, absence, illness)
**Not member of either House**: VP not member of Parliament or State Legislature (Art 66(4))
**Unique position**: Only constitutional functionary with dual role - Executive (VP) + Legislative (RS Chairman)

sections.heading: Election & Oath
points: **Art 66**: Elected by Electoral College of members of **both Houses of Parliament** (MPs only - no MLAs)
**System**: Proportional Representation by Single Transferable Vote; Secret ballot
**Qualifications (Art 66(3))**: Indian citizen, 35+ years, qualified to be RS member, not holding office of profit
**Term**: 5 years from entering office (Art 67); Can resign (to President); Removable by resolution
**Re-election**: Can be re-elected any number of times
**Oath**: Art 69 - Oath to preserve, protect, defend Constitution; Administered by President or person designated by President
**Salary**: â‚¹4 lakh/month (as VP); When acting as President, gets President's salary

sections.heading: Removal
points: **Art 67(b)**: Removed by resolution of Rajya Sabha passed by **absolute majority** (majority of total members) and agreed to by Lok Sabha
**Procedure**: Resolution originates in Rajya Sabha; 14 days' notice required; LS simply agrees (not re-passes with absolute majority)
**Not impeachment**: Removal procedure different from President (not called impeachment); Simpler process
**Grounds**: No specific grounds mentioned (unlike President - 'violation of Constitution'); Any reason acceptable to RS
**As RS Chairman**: Can be removed from Chairmanship by RS resolution (different from removal as VP)

sections.heading: Powers & Functions
points: **Ex-officio RS Chairman (Art 64)**: Presides over RS; Maintains order; Decides points of order; Does not vote ordinarily (only casting vote in tie)
**Acts as President (Art 65)**: When President's office vacant (death, resignation, removal) or President unable to discharge functions (illness, absence) â†’ VP discharges President's functions
**Duration as Acting President**: Till President resumes office OR new President elected (within 6 months - Art 62)
**Not automatically President**: VP does not become President; Only acts as President temporarily
**No executive powers as VP**: As VP (when not acting as President), has no executive powers; Only legislative function as RS Chairman
**Salary**: Gets salary as RS Chairman (â‚¹4 lakh) + allowances; When acting as President, gets President's salary

tabs.summary: **Vice President**: Elected by MPs only (no MLAs) via STV; 5-year term; Removable by RS resolution (absolute majority) agreed by LS. **Dual role**: (1) Ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha (Art 64), (2) Acts as President when President unable to discharge functions (Art 65). **No executive powers** as VP (only as Acting President). **Not member** of either House (Art 66(4)).

tabs.label: Prime Minister
tabs.title: Prime Minister of India (Art 75)

sections.heading: Constitutional Provision
points: **Art 75**: PM appointed by President; Other Ministers appointed by President on PM's advice
**Real Executive**: In Parliamentary system, PM is real head of government; President is nominal
**Leader of Majority**: PM is leader of majority party/coalition in Lok Sabha
**First among equals**: Traditionally called 'primus inter pares' (first among equals in Cabinet); But in practice, much more powerful
**Not much in Constitution**: Constitution has very few articles on PM (unlike President); Powers evolved through conventions

sections.heading: Appointment & Oath
points: **Appointed by President (Art 75(1))**: President appoints PM
**Convention**: President appoints leader of majority party in Lok Sabha as PM
**If no clear majority**: President may exercise discretion (invite largest party/coalition; Call for floor test)
**Qualifications**: Must be member of Parliament (LS or RS); If not, must become MP within 6 months (Art 75(5))
**No specific qualifications**: No age, citizenship qualifications specified in Constitution (unlike President/VP)
**Oath**: Art 75(4) - Oath of office and secrecy; Administered by President; Oath to uphold Constitution, perform duties faithfully
**Term**: No fixed term; Continues as long as enjoys confidence of Lok Sabha; Normally 5 years (if govt stable)

sections.heading: Removal
points: **No-confidence motion**: If Lok Sabha passes no-confidence motion (simple majority) â†’ PM and entire Council must resign (Art 75(3))
**Loss of confidence**: If PM loses confidence of LS (no-confidence passed OR defeat on confidence/money Bill) â†’ Must resign
**President cannot remove**: President cannot remove PM arbitrarily; PM removable only through LS (loss of confidence)
**Death/Resignation**: If PM dies or resigns â†’ President appoints new PM; Council of Ministers continues till new PM appointed

sections.heading: Powers - Relation with President
points: **Communicates decisions**: All Council of Ministers decisions communicated to President (Art 78)
**Advises President**: President acts on PM's advice (through Council of Ministers - Art 74)
**Appointment of Ministers**: PM recommends Ministers to President; President appoints on PM's advice (Art 75(1))
**Allocation of portfolios**: PM allocates and reshuffles portfolios among Ministers
**Seeks information**: President can ask PM to furnish information on administration and legislative proposals (Art 78)

sections.heading: Powers - Relation with Council of Ministers
points: **Chief of Council**: PM is head of Council of Ministers; Presides over Cabinet meetings
**Appoints & dismisses**: Recommends appointment and dismissal of Ministers to President
**Chairs Cabinet**: Chairs Cabinet, Cabinet Committees; Sets agenda for meetings
**Distributes portfolios**: Allocates, reshuffles, changes portfolios of Ministers
**Coordinates**: Coordinates work of different Ministries/Departments
**Final say**: In case of differences in Cabinet, PM's view usually prevails

sections.heading: Powers - Relation with Parliament
points: **Leader of House**: PM is Leader of Lok Sabha (if LS member) or has representative if RS member
**Advises dissolution**: Advises President to dissolve Lok Sabha (President bound to accept)
**Announces policies**: Announces government policies in Parliament
**Defends policies**: Defends government policies; Replies to debates, no-confidence motions
**Appoints leaders**: Recommends appointment of Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Leaders of Houses

sections.heading: Other Powers
points: **Head of government**: Chief spokesman of government; Represents India in international forums (along with President)
**Crisis management**: Leads during national crises, emergencies, disasters
**Appoints key functionaries**: Recommends appointment of CAG, Election Commissioners, CJI, Governors, Ambassadors, etc.
**National security**: Chairs Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS); Nuclear command authority vests in PM
**Policy formulation**: Key role in formulating domestic and foreign policies

tabs.summary: **Prime Minister**: Real executive head; Leader of majority in Lok Sabha; Appointed by President (Art 75); Must be MP (within 6 months). **Removable**: By no-confidence motion in LS (Art 75(3)). **Powers**: Appoints & dismisses Ministers; Allocates portfolios; Advises President; Chairs Cabinet; Leader of House; Dissolves LS. **Relation with President**: President acts on PM's advice (Art 74). **Most powerful**: In practice, much more than 'first among equals'.

tabs.label: Council of Ministers
tabs.title: Council of Ministers (Art 74-75)

sections.heading: Constitutional Provision
points: **Art 74**: Council of Ministers with PM as head to aid and advise President
**Art 75**: Composition, appointment, collective responsibility, individual responsibility
**Size**: No constitutional limit on size; PM decides (91st Amendment - Max 15% of LS strength)
**Portfolios**: PM allocates portfolios (Ministers with departments) or Ministers without portfolios

sections.heading: Appointment & Oath
points: **Appointed by President (Art 75(1))**: On advice of PM
**Qualifications**: Must be member of Parliament (LS or RS); If not, must become within 6 months (Art 75(5))
**Oath**: Art 75(4) - Oath of office and secrecy; Administered by President
**Term**: No fixed term; Serve at pleasure of President (actually PM)
**Removal**: President can remove on PM's advice; Or must resign if no-confidence passed in LS

sections.heading: Types of Ministers (Convention)
points: **1. Cabinet Ministers**: Senior-most; Head important Ministries; Members of Cabinet; Attend Cabinet meetings; Take major policy decisions
**2. Ministers of State (MoS)**: Junior Ministers; May have independent charge of Ministry OR assist Cabinet Minister
**3. Ministers of State (Independent Charge)**: Head smaller Ministries independently; Not Cabinet members but can attend Cabinet meetings if invited
**4. Deputy Ministers**: Lowest rank; Assist Ministers of State or Cabinet Ministers; Not Cabinet members
**91st Amendment 2003**: Limited Council size to 15% of LS strength (earlier no limit; Indira Gandhi had 60+ Ministers in 1970s)

sections.heading: Collective Responsibility (Art 75(3))
points: **Council collectively responsible to Lok Sabha**: All Ministers collectively responsible; Stand or fall together
**No-confidence**: If no-confidence passed against any Minister/policy â†’ Entire Council must resign (including PM)
**Solidarity**: All Ministers must support government decisions publicly; Cannot publicly disagree (even if disagreed in Cabinet)
**Resign together**: If govt loses confidence, all Ministers must resign together
**Basis of Parliamentary system**: Collective responsibility ensures govt accountable to people's representatives

sections.heading: Individual Responsibility
points: **For one's department**: Each Minister individually responsible for his/her Ministry/Department
**Answer to Parliament**: Must answer questions, defend policies of his/her Ministry in Parliament
**Resign if fault**: If serious lapse in Ministry, Minister expected to resign (convention, not constitutional)
**PM can dismiss**: PM can ask Minister to resign or recommend removal to President

sections.heading: Powers & Functions
points: **Policy formulation**: Formulate government policies (domestic, foreign, economic, etc.)
**Legislative**: Initiate legislation; Pilot Bills in Parliament; Defend government Bills
**Executive**: Implement laws; Administer Ministries/Departments; Execute government decisions
**Financial**: Prepare Budget; Authorize expenditure; Manage public finances
**Coordinate**: Coordinate between different Ministries; Resolve inter-ministerial disputes

sections.heading: Cabinet vs Council of Ministers
points: **Council of Ministers**: Includes ALL Ministers (Cabinet Ministers + MoS + Deputy Ministers); Larger body (50-80 members)
**Cabinet**: Inner core of Council; Only Cabinet Ministers (15-25 members); Takes major policy decisions
**Cabinet meetings**: Held regularly (usually weekly); Chaired by PM; Decisions binding on all Ministers
**Council meetings**: Rarely meet as full body; Too large for effective decision-making
**Real power**: Cabinet is real decision-making body; Council is formal constitutional body

sections.heading: Cabinet Committees
points: **Purpose**: Handle specific policy areas; Reduce Cabinet burden; Ensure focused decision-making
**Important committees**:
â€¢ **Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS)**: PM (Chair), Defence, Home, Finance, External Affairs Ministers
â€¢ **Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA)**: Economic policy, infrastructure, major projects
â€¢ **Cabinet Committee on Political Affairs (CCPA)**: Political issues, elections, key appointments
â€¢ **Appointments Committee of Cabinet (ACC)**: PM (Chair), Home Minister - Approves senior appointments
**Ad-hoc committees**: Formed for specific purposes; Dissolved after task completed

tabs.summary: **Council of Ministers**: Headed by PM; Aids and advises President (Art 74); Appointed by President on PM's advice. **Types**: Cabinet Ministers, MoS, MoS (Independent Charge), Deputy Ministers. **91st Amendment**: Max 15% of LS strength. **Collective responsibility** (Art 75(3)): All Ministers collectively responsible to LS; Stand/fall together; No-confidence â†’ All resign. **Individual responsibility**: Each Minister for his Ministry. **Cabinet**: Inner core; Real power; Takes major decisions.

data.summary: **Union Executive (Part V)**: Parliamentary system - Dual executive (President nominal, PM real). **President** (Art 52-62): Elected by Electoral College (MPs+MLAs) via STV; 5-year term; Impeachment for violation of Constitution (Art 61 - never used); Acts on Cabinet advice (Art 74 - 44th Amendment); Powers - Appoints PM/Ministers/Judges, Part of Parliament, Pardoning (Art 72), Ordinance (Art 123), Veto, Emergency. **Vice President** (Art 63-71): Elected by MPs via STV; Ex-officio RS Chairman (Art 64); Acts as President (Art 65); Removable by RS resolution + LS agreement. **Prime Minister** (Art 75): Real executive head; Leader of majority in LS; Appointed by President; Removable by no-confidence (Art 75(3)); Powers - Appoints Ministers, Allocates portfolios, Advises President, Chairs Cabinet, Dissolves LS. **Council of Ministers** (Art 74-75): Headed by PM; Collective responsibility to LS (Art 75(3)); Types - Cabinet, MoS, Deputy Ministers; Max 15% of LS (91st Amendment); Cabinet = Inner core, real power.
